text: in 2012 349 US service members killed
themselves that was 54 more soldiers
than were killed in Afghanistan that
same year if we start back in 2001 we
can see the rise in active duty suicides
still we should also contrast this with
civilian suicide rates now let's take a
closer look at what's happening to these
soldiers the latest and most detailed
Pentagon report on military suicides
comes from 2011 in that year a non
military issued firearm was the most
common way to commit suicide and the
majority of suicides occurred on US soil
now many people think combat exposure is
a likely factor in military suicides but
take a look at this only 6 percent of
these suicides witnessed killing in
combat in fact 85 percent
yes 85 percent had never experienced
direct fighting and more than half of
soldiers who killed themselves had never
even been deployed at all but perhaps
just serving during a time of war can
worsen pre-existing conditions maybe
it's a series of factors building upon
each other we can't totally be sure
almost half had experienced the failure
of an intimate relationship at least 1
in 5 were taking antidepressants some
experts have looked to physiological
reasons a study in 2009 found one in
five soldiers with traumatic brain
injuries reported thoughts of suicide
those with no history of TBI had none of
these thoughts as soldiers become
veterans the risk of suicide doesn't go
away even into their later years
according to a study in 21 states most
veteran suicides take place after 50
years old
David Botti BBC News Washington
you
